column2: # LMM with method as fixed effect, and task and subject as random effect
model <- lmer(formula = time ~ method + (1|task) + (1|subject), data = data)

We fitted a linear mixed model (estimated using REML and nloptwrap optimizer) to predict time with method (formula: time ~ method).
The model included task as random effects (formula: list(~1 | task, ~1 | subject)). The model's total explanatory power is
substantial (conditional R2 = 0.52) and the part related to the fixed effects alone (marginal R2) is of 0.06. The model's intercept,
corresponding to method = 0, is at 146.26 (95% CI [102.25, 190.27], t(102) = 6.59, p < .001). Within this model:

  - The effect of method [1] is statistically significant and positive (beta = 65.68, 95% CI [29.62, 101.74], t(102) = 3.61, p < .001;
Std. beta = 0.60, 95% CI [0.27, 0.93])
  - The effect of method [2] is statistically significant and positive (beta = 42.78, 95% CI [6.72, 78.85], t(102) = 2.35, p = 0.021;
Std. beta = 0.39, 95% CI [0.06, 0.72])

Standardized parameters were obtained by fitting the model on a standardized version of the dataset. 95% Confidence Intervals (CIs)
and p-values were computed using a Wald t-distribution approximation.
Linear mixed model fit by REML. t-tests use Satterthwaite's method ['lmerModLmerTest']
test = glht(model,linfct=mcp(method="Tukey")) # X ersetzen mit dem Name des Faktors
Simultaneous Tests for General Linear Hypotheses
lmer(formula = time ~ method + (1 | task) + (1 | subject), data = data)
